page.title: Main page - choose lesson part
page.contents:
You don't have to finish the lesson all in one sitting.  You can also retry it if you are not satisfied with how you did.  Here is a "map" of the lesson.  I am including this so that you can check whether you have completed all parts.  Note in particular that for some reason the moodle lessons sometimes skip the reflective writing items (I haven't figured out why), so this map helps you figure out where those should be:

Choose one of the following lesson parts.  When you have finished that part of the lesson you will be brought back to this page.  When you have finished all parts of the lesson click the "OK, I'm done" button to end the lesson.

Watch this lecture.

This covers some of the material in section 4-1 in the text.  If you have the text you may want to supplement the lecture by reading/skimming this section.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.

page.title: How will the cart move?
page.contents: When Geoff pulls on the cart with a steady force in the direction of motion which of the following is the best description of how the cart will move?

answer.answer_text: The cart will move at a steadily increasing speed.
answer.response: Yes, that's correct. You will see this in the next part of the video.

answer.answer_text: The cart will move at a constant speed.
answer.response: No. That is a common misconception. In the next part of the video you will see how an object moves when there is a steady force acting on it.

answer.answer_text: The cart will speed up for a short time and then move at a constant speed.
answer.response: No. That is a common misconception. In the next part of the video you will see how an object moves when there is a steady force acting on it.

answer.answer_text: The cart will move fast initially and then will move at a steadily decreasing speed.
answer.response: No. That is a common misconception. In the next part of the video you will see how an object moves when there is a steady force acting on it.

page.title: How does puck move
page.contents: After the air puck leaves Geoff's hand, which of the following is the best description of its motion?

answer.answer_text: The puck speeds up (Geoff is a Jedi).
The puck moves at constant speed.
The puck moves at constant speed, then slows down.

page.title: agent of weight
page.contents: You throw a ball downward off of a bridge.  After the ball leaves your hand there are only two forces acting on the ball: its weight and a drag force.  What is the agent of the weight force acting on the ball?

answer.response: Yes.
No that is just another name for this force. An agent of a force is always a physical object. Gravity is a force, not a physical object.

The weight is also called the "gravitational force". It is a common misconception that air is somehow responsible for gravity. But it is not. Have a look back at the part of the lecture where I talk about weight.
No. I can't pick myself up by my own shoelaces. The ball cannot pull down on itself.
Ha ha!

After the ball leaves your hand the only way your hand could exert a force on the ball would be if you were a Jedi. Since we don't actually live in the Star Wars universe, this answer is physically impossible.

page.title: Identify forces on box sliding across floor
page.contents: You kick a box. The box slides some distance across the floor after leaving contact with your foot. Choose all of the forces acting on the box and their agents after it has left contact with your foot but before it stops moving. (select all that apply)

answer.answer_text: Kinetic friction due to the floor.
answer.response: Yes.
Yes.

answer.answer_text: An upward normal force due to the floor.
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: A very small drag force due to the air.
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: A push due to your foot.
answer.response: No. We are thinking about forces acting on the box after it has left contact with your foot. The only way you could exert a force on the box after it leaves contact with your foot would be if you were a Jedi.

answer.answer_text: The inertia of the box which keeps it sliding.
answer.response: No. Inertia is not a force. It is "the idea" that things keep moving at constant speed in a straight line unless forces cause them to do otherwise. The box keeps moving because of inertia. But that doesn't mean inertia is a force. It is a statement of what happens in the absence of forces.

answer.answer_text: A downward normal force on the floor due to the box.
answer.response: No. That force exists, but it is a force acting on the floor. We are talking about forces which act on the box. You are mixing up the targets of the forces we are talking about.

page.title: Identify forces on a skater
page.contents: You are skating. You want a rest so you just let yourself glide for a while. Choose all of the forces acting on you and their agents.  (Select all that apply)

answer.answer_text: A normal force on you due to the ice surface.
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: A (small) kinetic friction force due to the ice surface.
answer.response: Yes. There would also be a small drag force due to the air.

answer.answer_text: Your weight due to the Earth.
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: Your inertia which keeps you going.
answer.response: No. Inertia is not a force. It is "the idea" that things keep moving at constant speed in a straight line unless forces cause them to do otherwise. You keep moving because of inertia. But that doesn't mean inertia is a force. It is a statement of what happens in the absence of forces.

answer.answer_text: A forward push due to your skates.
answer.response: No. You and your skates can be thought of as one object and you can't exert a force on yourself, just like I can't pick myself up by my own shoelaces. Also, there is no forward force on you here. The reason you keep moving has nothing to do with a force. It is the principle of inertia: objects keep moving in a straight line at constant speed unless forces cause them to do otherwise.

answer.answer_text: A downward normal force on the ice due to you.
answer.response: No. That force exists, but it is a force acting on the ice. We are talking about forces which act on you. You are mixing up the targets of the forces we are talking about.

page.title: Direction of acceleration from FBD - 1
page.contents:
Below is the free body diagram of a box that is sliding up and to the left on a ramp.

In which direction shown below will the box accelerate?

answer.response: Yes.
No. The box is going up the slope, but it is not accelerating up the slope. 1. Do you expect it to speed up or slow down? 2. Do the vector addition of the forces acting on the box.
No. If the box accelerated straight down then it would "dig into the ramp". This seems unlikely. You may be confusing acceleration due to gravity with the acceleration of the object.
No. You might be choosing an acceleration in the direction of the largest force. But the acceleration is in the direction of the vector sum of the forces.

No. Perhaps you think that because the box is slowing down (presumably...) that it is not accelerating. Remember that acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. The velocity of this box is changing (it is slowing down). So it is accelerating. So it's acceleration is not zero.

page.title: Pulling a box at constant velocity
page.contents:
You are pulling a box across the floor at constant speed in a straight line using a rope as shown.

Which of the following is the correct free body diagram for the box?

answer.response: Yes.

No. First of all, this FBD is missing a lot of forces. Think of what agents the box is in contact with and what contact forces they should exert on it. Second of all, the box is moving at constant speed in a straight line (in other words, it moves at constant velocity). So F<sub>net</sub> is zero.
No. The forces on this FBD are correct. But the box is moving at constant speed in a straight line (in other words, it moves at constant velocity). So F<sub>net</sub> is zero.

No. First of all, the box is moving at constant speed in a straight line (in other words, it moves at constant velocity). So F<sub>net</sub> is zero. Second of all, the horizontal force labelled "ma" has no agent which could exert it. This force can't exist.

No. First of all, the box is in contact with the floor and sliding over it. So there should be a friction force. Second of all, it is true that F<sub>net</sub> is zero since the box is moving with a constant velocity. But the forces drawn on the FBD cannot possibly add up to zero, so the FBD is inconsistent with the net force.

page.title: box sliding up incline
page.contents:
You have kicked a box up a ramp.  It is now sliding up the ramp and is not in contact with your foot.  The box is slowing down.

Which of the free body diagrams below is the most correct for this box?

answer.response: yes

No. The box is not in contact with your foot. So there is no agent which could be responsible for the F_push in this FBD. Also the normal force should be perpendicular to the ramp, not straight up, and the box is sliding on the ramp so the ramp should be exerting a friction force on it. Finally, the box is slowing down, so the net force is in the wrong direction.
No. The box is not in contact with your foot. So there is no agent which could be responsible for the F_push in this FBD.
No. The normal force should be perpendicular to the ramp, not straight up. Also, the box is slowing down, so the net force is in the wrong direction in this FBD.
No. The box is slowing down, so the net force is in the wrong direction in this FBD.

page.title: Direction of acceleration from FBD - 2
page.contents:
Below is the free body diagram of a piece of machinery being lifted by two ropes.

In which direction shown below will the piece of machinery accelerate?

answer.response: Yes.
No. Perhaps you think it is up because the largest force acting on the machine is acting up. But the acceleration is in the direction of the vector sum of the forces.
No. Perhaps you are confusing the acceleration with the acceleration due to gravity. An object accelerates in the direction of the vector sum of the forces acting on it.
No. The upward tension is bigger than the weight and the other tension also has an upward component. So the vector sum of the forces must have an upward component.
No. There is no way the vector sum of these forces is zero, so the acceleration cannot be zero.

page.title: All reflections
page.contents:
This is only here so that if the Lesson navigation failed and you couldn't access one of the Reflective Writing pages you can view their content here.  Most of the time there should be no need for you to visit this page.

----------After Lecture 2-----------

Take out a piece of paper.  Write "PHYS 1101 - Response to Unit 5 Video Lectures" across the top of the paper and put your name in an upper corner of the page.  Write a big heading saying "Lectures 1-2".  

Under that answer these questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Something you have seen before: Identify something from any of the videos on this unit that you have seen before.  If it was presented differently from how you have seen it previously then briefly describe the difference.  It is not acceptable to say that nothing in the videos was something you have seen before.  All knowledge is built on earlier knowledge and there must be something in these videos that was at least somewhat familiar.

3. For each of the following forces, identify the agent of the force, and say whether the force is a contact force or a long-range force.

(a) The force which causes a book to slow down when it is sliding across a desk.

(b) The force which causes a  wine glass  to accelerate downward after someone has knocked  it off a  table (to be clear, the person is not touching the glass during the time we are interested in).

(c) The force that attracts a fridge magnet to the  surface  of your fridge.

(d) The force that causes a sailboat to speed up during a strong gust of wind.

You will add more to this sheet after some of the other lectures in this unit.

------------After Lecture 5-----------

You should already have a sheet of paper that you wrote some things on after watching Lectures 1-2.  If you don't already have that (perhaps because you are watching the videos out of sequence) then go back to Lecture 2, watch it, answer the questions and then start your writing.  Then come back to this page.

Under what you wrote for Lectures 1-2 write a heading saying "End of Lesson".  

Under that heading answer the following questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. Suppose we have an object and we know its mass.  Suppose that at some moment we also know all of the forces acting on the object (i.e. we know their magnitudes and directions).  What does this allow us to predict about the object's motion?

You will scan this sheet, along with an addition to your cheat sheet, and submit it on moodle under the Written Response for this lesson.

page.contents:
Take out a piece of paper.  Write "PHYS 1101 - Response to Unit 5 Video Lectures" across the top of the paper and put your name in an upper corner of the page.  Write a big heading saying "Lectures 1-2".  

Under that answer these questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Something you have seen before: Identify something from any of the videos on this unit that you have seen before.  If it was presented differently from how you have seen it previously then briefly describe the difference.  It is not acceptable to say that nothing in the videos was something you have seen before.  All knowledge is built on earlier knowledge and there must be something in these videos that was at least somewhat familiar.

3. For each of the following forces, identify the agent of the force, and say whether the force is a contact force or a long-range force.

(a) The force which causes a book to slow down when it is sliding across a desk.

(b) The force which causes a  wine glass  to accelerate downward after someone has knocked  it off a  table (to be clear, the person is not touching the glass during the time we are interested in).

(c) The force that attracts a fridge magnet to the  surface  of your fridge.

(d) The force that causes a sailboat to speed up during a strong gust of wind.

You will add more to this sheet after some of the other lectures in this unit.

page.title: Rank accelerations of three objects - 1
page.contents:
Block A has a mass of 1.0 kg.  The net force on it is 2.0 N.

Block B has a mass of 2.0 kg.  The net force on it is 2.0 N.

Block C has a mass of 0.5 kg.  The net force on it is 1.0 N.

Rank the magnitudes of the accelerations of these three blocks.

answer.response: Yes.
No. I think you are multiplying the forces by the masses. But a = F/m.
No. You have just ranked the forces. But the masses are important as well.
No. You have just ranked them from least massive to most massive. But the forces exerted on them are also important.

page.title: Rank accelerations of three objects - 2
page.contents:
Three crates are being pulled across ice using ropes.  We can ignore gravity and the normal force (because they cancel each other) and friction is small enough that we can ignore it as well.  The crates, the tensions in the ropes are as follows:

Crate A has mass 10 kg and the tension in the rope pulling it is 6.0 N.

Crate B has mass 5 kg and the tension in the rope pulling it is 12 N.

Crate C has mass 20 kg and the tension in the rope pulling it is 12 N.

Rank the magnitudes of the accelerations of these three crates.

answer.response: Yes.
No. I think you've just ranked them by the forces. But the masses matter as well.
No. I think you've just ranked them from least massive to most massive. But the forces matter as well.
No. I think you multiplied all of the forces by the masses and then ranked the results. But a = F/m.

page.title: Agent of frictional force
page.contents: A block is sliding down an inclined surface. There is a frictional force acting on it. The source (agent) of the friction force that acts on the block is

answer.answer_text: the surface that the block is on.
answer.response: Yes.
I can't pick myself up by my own shoelaces. The block can't exert a force on itself.
No. First of all, air drag is a separate force from friction. Second of all, the agent of a force is always a physical object. Air drag is a force, not a physical object.
No. First of all, gravity (weight) is a separate force from friction. Second of all, the agent of a force is always a physical object. Gravity is a force, not a physical object.
No. The friction force we are talking about here *is* a kinetic friction force. But what is meant by "agent" is the physical object which causes the force.
No. The agent of a force is always a physical object. The motion of the block is not a physical object.

page.title: Agent of force on you
page.contents: As you are sitting at a computer doing this quiz there are forces acting upon you. One is your weight, which pulls you down. If there were no other force acting on you then you would accelerate down (falling through the chair, the floor, etc.). So there must be an upward force acting on you. The agent (source) of this upward force is

answer.answer_text: the chair and floor that are under you.
answer.response: Yes.
No. I can't lift myself up by my shoelaces. You can't exert a force upward on yourself.

No. There is a **tiny** upward force exerted on you by the air. This is buoyancy. But we can safely ignore buoyancy in a case like this. If buoyancy kept you from falling you would be able to step out of your window and float.
No. That is the *name* of the force which keeps you from falling through the floor. The agent is the physical object which causes this force.
Ha, ha!

page.title: Reflect on what you have learned (final summary)
page.contents:
You should already have a sheet of paper that you wrote some things on after watching Lecture ###.  If you don't already have that (perhaps because you are watching the videos out of sequence) then go back to Lecture 2, watch it, answer the questions and then start your writing.  Then come back to this page.

Under what you wrote for Lecture 2 write a heading saying "End of Lectures".  

Under that heading answer the following questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. Suppose we have an object and we know its mass.  Suppose that at some moment we also know all of the forces acting on the object (i.e. we know their magnitudes and directions).  What does this allow us to predict about the object's motion?

You will scan this sheet, along with an addition to your cheat sheet, and submit it on moodle under the Written Response for this lesson.
